title: 4 Best Ways to Make Slime Less Sticky (With or without an Activator)

steps.title: Add ½ teaspoon (2 g) of baking soda.
steps.content: Add ½ teaspoon (2 g) of baking soda. Sprinkle the baking soda over your slime and use your hands to knead it in until it’s not sticky anymore. If it still feels sticky, add ⅛ teaspoon (½ g) more and keep kneading. [1] X Research source Careful not to add too much baking soda or it will make your slime less stretchy ! Knead the slime thoroughly before adding more.

steps.title: Alternatively, add 1 teaspoon (5 mL) of contact solution.
steps.content: Alternatively, add 1 teaspoon (5 mL) of contact solution. Pour the contact solution over your slime, then work it in with your hands until the slime doesn’t feel sticky anymore. If that doesn’t cut it, add another ¼ teaspoon (1 ¼ mL) of contact solution. [2] X Research source Add contact solution just a little bit at a time. Too much will make your slime rubbery. If your slime recipe used liquid starch as an activator instead of contact solution try adding more liquid starch instead.

steps.title: Try adding 1 teaspoon (5 mL) of baby oil.
steps.content: Try adding 1 teaspoon (5 mL) of baby oil. Baby oil is a common ingredient in shiny slime recipes, and it can also make your slime less sticky. Knead the baby oil into your slime until it’s all mixed in and the slime doesn’t feel sticky anymore. [3] X Research source Don’t add more than 1 teaspoon (5 mL) of baby oil or your slime may become goopy and lose its stretchiness (and nobody wants that!).

steps.title: Knead your slime more—sometimes that’s enough to make it less sticky!
steps.content: Knead your slime more—sometimes that’s enough to make it less sticky! If you don’t want to add anything else to your slime, keep kneading it. It helps the ingredients combine better and carry out their chemical reactions, meaning less stickiness. Press the slime with your hands and fingers, stretch it out, form it back into a ball, and press it out again. Continue doing this until your slime feels less sticky. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add 8 tablespoons (about 120 mL) of white school glue to a bowl.
steps.content: Add 8 tablespoons (about 120 mL) of white school glue to a bowl. Plain white school glue works best with this recipe. Don’t use clear or glittered school glue. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Stir in 2-3 drops of food coloring if you want colorful slime.
steps.content: Stir in 2-3 drops of food coloring if you want colorful slime. You don't have to do this, but it will make your slime more beautiful ! If you skip the food coloring, your slime will come out white (white slime’s cool, too). Stir in the food coloring until there are no streaks. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Add 1 ½ cups (360 g) of shaving cream.
steps.content: Add 1 ½ cups (360 g) of shaving cream. The amount doesn’t have to be exact. Make sure you’re using the basic, foaming kind of shaving cream and not the gel kind. [7] X Research source White shaving cream is best because it won't change the color of your slime.

steps.title: Stir everything together until the ingredients are fully combined.
steps.content: Stir everything together until the ingredients are fully combined. Use a spoon or rubber spatula. As you stir, scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl so that everything gets mixed in. As the ingredients come together, you’ll end up with fluffy slime . [8] X Research source The slime may be sticky at this point. Don't worry, you still have 1 more ingredient to add!

steps.title: Add 2 ½ tablespoons (37 ½ mL) of contact solution.
steps.content: Add 2 ½ tablespoons (37 ½ mL) of contact solution. Slowly pour the contact solution into the slime while stirring. Keep stirring until the slime starts to leave the sides of the bowl. You might not actually need all of the contact solution. [9] X Research source Use contact solution that contains boric acid. Fortunately, most contact solutions contain this ingredient!

steps.title: Knead the slime until it’s not sticky.
steps.content: Knead the slime until it’s not sticky. Pick the slime up with your hands (it will be a little sticky at this point—that’s normal!) and knead it by stretching it out, then squishing it back together. Keep doing this for a few minutes until the slime isn’t sticky. [10] X Research source If your slime is still sticky, add ¼ teaspoon (1 ¼ mL) more of contact solution and knead it again.

steps.title: Store your slime
steps.content: Store your slime in an airtight container when you're not using it. This slime will last for about 1-2 days. After that, it will dry out. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Pour 8 tablespoons (120 mL) of white school glue into a bowl.
steps.content: Pour 8 tablespoons (120 mL) of white school glue into a bowl. Avoid using clear school glue for this slime since it won’t work the same. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Stir in ½ teaspoon (2.5 mL) of laundry detergent at a time until slime forms.
steps.content: Stir in ½ teaspoon (2.5 mL) of laundry detergent at a time until slime forms. You’ll know you’ve added enough detergent when the glue starts to clump together and leave the sides of the bowl. How much you’ll need depends on the brand you’re using, but it will likely be about 7 ½ teaspoons (37 mL). [13] X Research source Choose a laundry detergent with a color and smell that you like. Your slime will end up having a similar color and smell!

steps.title: Mix 1 teaspoon (4g) of baking soda and 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of water in a separate cup.
steps.content: Mix 1 teaspoon (4g) of baking soda and 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of water in a separate cup. No need to be precise here. You just want a solution that looks like cloudy water. If the solution is so thick that your spoon leaves streaks in it, add more water. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Add 1 teaspoon (5 mL) of the baking soda solution to the slime at a time.
steps.content: Add 1 teaspoon (5 mL) of the baking soda solution to the slime at a time. Stir the slime, then add more baking soda solution until the slime is no longer sticky. You might end up not using all of the baking soda solution. [15] X Research source If you run out of baking soda solution and still need some, go ahead and make more.

steps.title: Knead the slime.
steps.content: Knead the slime. Take the slime out of the bowl, stretch it out, then squish it back together. Do this a few times. As you continue to knead the slime, you'll notice it becoming less and less sticky.

steps.title: Store the slime in a sealed container when you're not using it.
steps.content: Store the slime in a sealed container when you're not using it. Your slime should last 2-3 days before starting to dry out. Play with it while you can, then make more!

steps.title: Start with 8 tablespoons (120 mL) of white school glue in a bowl.
steps.content: Start with 8 tablespoons (120 mL) of white school glue in a bowl. Make sure you use white glue and not clear glue for this slime. Clear glue won’t work! [16] X Research source

steps.title: Add ½ tablespoon (7 ½ g) of baking soda.
steps.content: Add ½ tablespoon (7 ½ g) of baking soda. Use a spoon or rubber spatula to stir it into the glue. You might notice the glue starting to thicken, which is normal. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Add 2-3 drops of food coloring.
steps.content: Add 2-3 drops of food coloring. While food coloring isn’t a must, it will make your slime more vibrant and colorful. Without any food coloring, your slime will be white. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Stir in 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of contact solution.
steps.content: Stir in 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of contact solution. The contact solution will cause the rest of the ingredients to come together and form a slime. Keep stirring until the ingredients leave the sides of the bowl. [19] X Research source Make sure you use contact solution containing boric acid. Most contact solutions do. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Knead the slime until it’s less sticky.
steps.content: Knead the slime until it’s less sticky. Pull it apart with your hands, then clump it back together. Do this for a few minutes until it doesn’t feel sticky anymore. At that point, your slime is complete! [21] X Research source

steps.title: Add more contact solution, if needed.
steps.content: Add more contact solution, if needed. If your slime feels too sticky even after you knead it, add ¼ tablespoon (3 ¾ mL) more contact solution and then keep kneading. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Stash the slime in an airtight container when you're done playing with it.
steps.content: Stash the slime in an airtight container when you're done playing with it. Your slime will last 2-3 days, so enjoy it while you can!

steps.title: Add 10 tablespoons (150 mL) of clear school glue to a bowl.
steps.content: Add 10 tablespoons (150 mL) of clear school glue to a bowl. For this recipe, make sure you’re using clear school glue and not white glue. White glue won’t work with the other ingredients! [23] X Research source

steps.title: Mix 1 teaspoon (4 g) of baking soda into the glue.
steps.content: Mix 1 teaspoon (4 g) of baking soda into the glue. Stir with a spoon or rubber spatula until the baking soda and glue are completely mixed together. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Add 2 tablespoons (47 g) of colored craft sand.
steps.content: Add 2 tablespoons (47 g) of colored craft sand . Colored aquarium sand works too! Stir everything together until the sand is evenly mixed in. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Stir 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of contact solution into the slime.
steps.content: Stir 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of contact solution into the slime. Keep stirring until the slime leaves the sides of the bowl. [26] X Research source You’ll need contact solution that contains boric acid, an ingredient that’s found in most types of contact solution. [27] X Research source

steps.title: Knead the slime, then add more contact solution if it’s still sticky.
steps.content: Knead the slime, then add more contact solution if it’s still sticky. Pull the slime between your fingers and then squish it back together. Do this a few more times until the slime feels less sticky. If it still feels sticky, add ½ tablespoon (7 ½ mL) more of contact solution, and knead again. [28] X Research source

steps.title: Make different colored slimes and mix them together for a cool effect.
steps.content: Make different colored slimes and mix them together for a cool effect. Repeat the steps above for each color you want to make. Then, squish them together into a big blob. The colors will create a streaked, galaxy-like effect. [29] X Research source

steps.title: Keep your slime in a sealed container when you're not using it.
steps.content: Keep your slime in a sealed container when you're not using it. Your slime will eventually dry out and harden. To help it last longer, store it in a sealed container when you’re not playing with it.
